title: How to Wash a Ski Jacket

steps.headline: Add 1 capful of technical down cleaner to your machine.
steps.description: Normal detergent strips the natural oils out of your down jacket. Add 1 capful of down cleaner to your machine wherever you normally put detergent. You can find down cleaner at most sporting good stores.Tip: If your washer has detergent residue in it, run a rinse cycle without any clothes in the washer to clean it before you wash your jacket.

steps.headline: Set your washer to medium heat on a gentle setting.
steps.description: Warm water keeps the down fluffy and avoids clumping. Use a gentle setting to avoid your jacket spinning too much in the cycle. Always wash your jacket on its own.

steps.headline: Rinse the jacket a second time in the washer.
steps.description: It is important to rinse your jacket twice to get rid of any residue that could be left on it. Set your washer to a rinse cycle with warm water and let it run. Rinse cycles will not take as long as full wash cycles, so it won’t add a ton of time to your wash.

steps.headline: Put your jacket in the dryer with 2 to 3 tennis balls.
steps.description: Tennis balls work to break up clumps of down while your jacket is drying. Add a couple of clean, unused tennis balls to your dryer before you turn it on. You can buy tennis balls at most sporting good stores. You can also use dryer balls if you have them.

steps.headline: Set your dryer on a low heat and check it every 30 minutes.
steps.description: You may need to turn your jacket inside-out or reconfigure it periodically to help it dry. Check on your jacket every 30 minutes until it is fully dry. This could take upwards of 3 hours. Check to make sure the down isn’t coming out of your jacket anywhere.

steps.headline: Fill a large bucket or tub with cold water.
steps.description: Synthetic insulation is very delicate and can get ripped or damaged in a washing machine. Use a bathtub or a large bucket that will hold enough water to cover your jacket.

steps.headline: Pour 1 capful of synthetic insulation detergent in your water.
steps.description: Synthetic insulation requires a specific type of detergent. Add 1 capful of synthetic insulation detergent made specifically for synthetic insulation to your cold water. You can buy these specialized detergents at most sporting good stores or wherever you bought your jacket.

steps.headline: Scrub your jacket with your hands for 10 minutes.
steps.description: Use your hands to wash your jacket in the cold water. Squish and squeeze the jacket to make sure the detergent covers the whole thing. Pay special attention to any stained or particularly dirty areas. Do not use a sponge or washcloth to scrub your jacket. These are too harsh for the protective layer.

steps.headline: Rinse with cold water to make sure there is no residue left behind.
steps.description: Pour out your detergent-filled water and rinse your jacket thoroughly. Be sure the jacket is completely free of any detergent residue. You may need to rinse your jacket more than once.Tip: The best way to rinse your jacket is in a tub.

steps.headline: Dry your jacket on a low temperature and check it every 20 minutes.
steps.description: You may need to readjust your jacket or turn it inside out to make sure that it is dry. Take the jacket out and hang it to store once it is fully dry. If you are worried about your insulation clumping, put 2 or 3 tennis balls in the dryer with your jacket.

steps.headline: Check the label on your jacket for the manufacturer’s recommendation.
steps.description: Although most jackets will have the same washing instructions, always double-check to see what your particular jacket recommends. Look at the label that is usually on the neck of your jacket to see what its washing instructions are. A popular waterproof jacket brand is Gore-Tex.

steps.headline: Zip up your jacket and close all of the pockets.
steps.description: Leaving zippers open can make your pockets snag on the inside of your washer. Close any pockets and secure any velcro flaps or straps on your jacket. Check all your pockets before you close them to make sure there is nothing in them, like lip balm or loose bills.

steps.headline: Pour 1 capful of liquid detergent into your washing machine.
steps.description: You can use any kind of mild liquid detergent that you have on hand since waterproof jackets are pretty hardy. Use 1 capful for 1 jacket and pour it wherever you would pour detergent normally.Warning: Never use powder detergents, softeners, or bleach, as they can damage your jacket.

steps.headline: Set your washer on a low spin setting in warm water.
steps.description: Warm water will not harm your jacket and can help remove tough stains. Choose a low spin setting on your machine to avoid spinning the jacket too much and causing damage. Your jacket should always be washed on its own. You can wash your jacket in cold water if you prefer, but never hot water as this could damage the waterproof material.

steps.headline: Rinse the jacket a second time in the washer.
steps.description: Once your jacket is done with its initial cycle, set your washer to spin again to get rid of any detergent residue that has been left on your jacket. You can use warm or cold water for your second rinse.

steps.headline: Hang your jacket to air dry.
steps.description: Dryers are too harsh for waterproof jackets to dry completely. Put your jacket on a hanger and let it air dry completely. This could take anywhere from a few hours to a full day. You can wear your jacket once it is completely dry, but the waterproof layer may not be fully functional.

steps.headline: Put your jacket in the dryer for 20 minutes.
steps.description: In order to re-activate the waterproof outer layer, your jacket needs to be exposed to heat. Set your dryer to a regular temperature setting and choose a 20-minute cycle. Take your jacket out of the dryer as soon as 20 minutes are up and hang it up.
